title: A curvy but squarish sans.
content:
Oxymoronic? Maybe. I don't know if I'm setting myself up for failure with those parameters, but whatever. I'd like to hear some suggestions on improvements. Are the mini-flourishes just looking weird when on a squarish face? [For anyone who cares](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417083129/http:/notes.salsen.com/?p=177) about how it started.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417083129im_/http:/typophile.com/files/sans_large_4205.gif)
author: kosal

comments.content:
This reminds me a bit of [Lexicon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417083129/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/lexicon/index.html) with the mini flourishes. I think the bottom of 'S' needs work. The curve looks too flat to my eyes.

-Eric MacLeod
Thanks for the input, it's actually the s/S which I'm having the most problems with.

Interesting, challenging project. The curved terminals have charm but are a tough fit as you acknowledge. Maybe if the strokes weren't so insistently monoline (introducing a slight consistent contrast, or thinning bowl strokes as they intersect more dramatically), the thinning flourishes would be a better fit.

Are the flourishes on the figures much more pronounced on purpose? That 9 seems unbalanced, and also may be violating the open apertures you talked about on your website.

I'd make the ear of the g more old-fashioned, curved and "flourished."
